Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a frequency parameter and \\( i \\) the imaginary unit. This function represents the solution to the linear differential equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\). We examine the effect of applying a linear operator, represented by matrix A, to alter the function: \\( f(z) = Az \\).

If we apply the operator \\( f(z) \\) at time t = 0 to \\( z_0 \\) and let the system evolve under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\) without further intervention, will the function \\( z(t) \\) at any future time t = T be the same as if no operator A was applied initially?
Explanation: Applying the operator \\( f(z) = Az \\) modifies the initial condition \\( z_0 \\) to \\( Az_0 \\). Since the differential equation is linear, the solution with transformed initial condition will be \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t}Az_0 \\), which is generally different from \\( e^{i\\omega t}z_0 \\) unless A commutes with the evolution operator \\( e^{i\\omega t} \\).
